A black box in the car ?

American street planners are looking for a source of money to repair the falling Highway system , and believe that the solution has been found in a small black box that fits in the dashboard of every car .

The devices that record every kilometer and report the information to the authorities are central to a controversial attempt by Washington and state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The normally rather boring area of road planning has suddenly sparked intense debate with colorful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups and argue that the government can use the small boxes to record the miles – and possibly where they have been driven – and then use the information to calculate tax moderation .
The Tea Party is appalled .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while congressional action cannot be agreed , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently examining how they can change over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of motorists have already tested the tachograph , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .
This really is a must for our country .

“ It ’ s nothing that we may only use , ” said Hasan Ihrata , managing director of the Southern California Assn . of Governements , who plans to record the miles taken by all Californian motorists in the state from 2025 onwards .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed by the taxes paid by Americans at the fuel dispensers , is bankrupt .
But America is no longer dancing as much as it used to be .
Cars consume less petrol .
The state oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 euro cents per litre ) has not risen for 20 years .
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax by one cent at high fuel prices .
“ The gasoline tax is simply not sustainable , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert on traffic legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His state recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a payments system based on miles .
“ That is the most sensible alternative in the long term , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a meillebased user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea is appealing to urban liberals , because the tax could be used , for example , to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and harmful emissions from the climate .
California planners are relying on the system to develop strategies to meet the federal state ’ s ambitious , legally anchored climate change targets .
But the Republican Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also said that he sees it as the most viable long-term alternative .
The independent marketers of the Reason Foundation are also inspired by the idea of paying drivers after a short distance .
“ This is not a tax that disappears into a black hole , ” explains Adrian Moore , Vice President of Policies at Reason .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two previous US transport ministers , who , in a 2011 report , called on Congress to move toward meille-based accounting .
The US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project last year that would have included 10,000 cars .
But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the move , responding to the concerns of rural MPs representing people who often travel many miles to work or to the city in everyday life .
Several states and major cities nonetheless move in this direction on their own .
The most dedicated is Oregon , which is currently recruiting 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s largest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay the cost of miles instead of the mineral oil tax to the state .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering this .
Illinois tests it to a limited extent with trucks .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the Department of Transportation of 17 East Coast states ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is now exploring how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with equipment , motorists were skeptical about the government ’ s ability to follow any of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a big problem , ” says Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Results Management at the Department of Transportation in Nevada .
People did not want it .
When the test started , the Nevada ACLU warned on its website , “ It would be relatively easy to turn the tachograph into full-fledged surveillance devices . ”
There is no need to build a gigantic , unwieldy technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to gather data about individuals ’ daily movements .
Nevada is one of a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology that allows the state to capture the kilometres travelled , but not exactly when and where .
That , Khan said , would also reassure the public .
Hunting for this technology has led some authorities to a small start-up company called True Mileage in California .
The company originally did not plan to help states tax drivers .
Rather , it was its goal to gain traction in an emerging market for car insurance , where drivers are to pay on the basis of mileage .
However , the devices they test are also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and locations are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , Managing Director of True Mileage .
Some of these public pilot programmes have made great mistakes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways of doing this .
In Oregon , planners are experimenting with offering motorists a variety of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .
Or they choose no device at all and instead pay a flat fee based on the average miles travelled by all state residents .
Others hope to be able to sell the concept of a distrustful public by providing the devices with more functions than with less .

In New York City , road officials want to develop a tax system that also pays parking fees , pays insurance only for kilometres travelled , and collects speed data from other vehicles in real time , enabling motorists to avoid traffic jams .
“ Drivers would be motivated to participate by the added value of the benefits offered by the system , ” says a city planning document .
However , some road planners wonder whether all the talk of paying per mile is not just a huge diversion .

Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the San Francisco Bay Area declared that Congress could solve the problem of the bankrupt Highway Trust Fund simply by increasing fuel tax .
An additional one-time fee or an annual levy could be imposed on motorists with hybrid vehicles or other vehicles that use less petrol , so that they also pay a fair share .
“ There is no reason for an operation if an aspirin is sufficient , ” says Randy Rentschler , the Commission ’ s head of legislation and public affairs .
If we do that , hundreds of millions of motorists worry about their privacy and many other things .

US border : " super tunnel " to drug smuggling discovered .
On the border between Mexico and the US , investigators have discovered and closed a " super tunnel " to drug smuggling .
As US customs officials said , the more than 500 meter long tube between Tijuana and San Diego was equipped with electricity , railway tracks , and a ventilation system .
Three suspects were arrested , eight tonnes of marijuana and nearly 150 kilograms of cocaine seized .
According to the data , the tunnel had not yet been used .

These cartels are stupid if they think they could dig themselves under the radar ,  said the Attorney General of the District Southern California , Laura Duffy , at a press conference in front of a warehouse in San Diego , where an end to the tunnel had been discovered .
Turning to the drug gangs , Duffy assured : " If you continue to build such tunnels and try to use them , we are determined to make this a huge waste of your dirty money " .
Both the US authorities and the Mexican security forces are in a permanent war against the drug cartels .
Since 2006 , more than 77,000 people have been killed in Mexico in connection with drug-related crime .
Designed by Experts
Due to the complex equipment of the tunnel , the investigators assume that it was constructed by architects and engineers and that it took about a year .
The track position was so equipped that electrically operated cars could be used there .
On the Mexican side , access is in a building 80 meters from the border .
According to the authorities , a ladder leads to the actual tunnel entrance 20 metres in depth .
The tunnel has a cross section of 1,20 meters in height and 90 centimeters in width .
It would also have been appropriate to promote illegal immigration towards the US .
Two of the suspects were arrested in connection with cocaine .
The third , a Mexican , was caught because of the confiscated marijuana .
All three are in danger of being deprived of life as a maximum sentence , as officials have said .
Eight such tunnels have been discovered since 2006 , and the press conference in San Diego continued .
But it is the first time that cocaine has been found in such a tunnel construction .
Normally cocaine is smuggled in smaller quantities , not through tunnels .
This shows the " despair " of drug gangs whose traditional routes are now cut off , Bill Sherman said of the drug trail DEA in San Diego .

Esa decides on big space missions : missions for billions .
Far off planets , gravitational waves or black holes - European space agency experts must now agree on two major projects that they intend to launch in the coming years .
30 suggestions were available , five are still in the race .
Far worlds .
Astronomers have already found more than 1000 planets in other stars .
No one knows whether there is any life , at least in some of them .
The choice is difficult : should you search for gravitational waves ?
Or rather explore the origins of the cosmos ?
Or to search for earthlike planets and thus perhaps discover extra-terrestrial life ?
These are the questions raised by those responsible for the European Space Agency Esa .
For their " Cosmic Vision " program , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that will make a decisive contribution to research .
The budget for such " L missions " is about one billion euros each .
The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .
At the beginning of September the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
Thirty ideas were on the table , five of which have now been shortlisted .
Many bodies are examining the proposals and following the advice of researchers .
A final decision will be taken by the Scientific Programme Committee in the next few days .
The Esa has selected four major questions to which the missions of the 2007 program " Cosmic Vision " will find answers .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and lives ?
The exact processes of the formation of stars from large gas clouds - and thus the formation of planets that circle these stars - are still in the proverbial dark .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this darkness .
And when a star has a planet , under what circumstances can life be created there ?
To address this question , the Space Telescope " Cheops " will be launched in 2017 , which will examine more closely 500 known planetary systems in our vicinity .
The possibilities are limited , however , Cheops is a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could map earth-like planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres , searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , is ultimately intended to shed light on the conditions for the emergence of life .
The magnetic activity of a star plays an important role in the interaction of its magnetic field and particle radiation with the planetary system .
In our solar system , these processes can be investigated in an exemplary way .
With the Solar Orbiter , the Esa has already approved a M-Class mission ( there the budget is about half a billion euros ) for this issue .
The probe will launch in 2017 and closely observe the surface and activity of the sun .
Jupiter and its moons are also of great interest to the researchers .
You want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system .
This is the first of the three L missions of the " Cosmic Vision " program .
The probe " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is expected to begin its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later it reaches Jupiter and is said to study the atmosphere of the planet as well as the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
The universe offers many possibilities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature known to us are still valid there .
Perhaps there are also deviations that could lead the physicists to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
How was the universe created and what is it made of ?
13.7 billion years ago our cosmos was created by the big bang .
In addition to the common matter of stars , planets , and creatures like us , dark matter holds galaxies and galaxy clusters together , and dark energy that accelerates the expansion of space .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first split seconds of the Big Bang , nor what dark matter and dark energy existed .
With Euclid , the Esa has already approved a M mission to launch in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe is intended for the first time to examine the distribution of matter in the universe throughout the sky , allowing conclusions about the nature of Dark Matter and Dark Energy .
Who Could Race
Of the 30 proposals , only two will remain at the end of the selection process .
In the opinion of many experts " E-Lisa " , the best chances for an L-mission approval has a challenging concept for the detection of gravitational waves .
Physicists understand changes in the structure of space time that Albert Einstein predicted nearly 100 years ago .
They have not yet been rejected .
Elisa could do that , the scientists hope behind the project .
The mission envisages a detector consisting of two or three probes , which will be stationed in space .
In contrast to Earth 's facilities , it could also prove gravitational waves that were created during the Big Bang , providing new insights into the universe 's development .

Four other proposals still compete for the second L mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is to explore black holes , " Icy Planets " , another mission to the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure cosmic background radiation , and the " Exopoplanet Finder " , which is supposed to detect and study Earth like planets .
Some of the proposals for sample return transport from Mars , for research on moon , Venus and asteroids , and for solar physics have already been withdrawn .

What happens on the move with my email ?
Email actually means electronic mail .
Did the concept of the Internet service , like the traditional postal service , technically implement the confidentiality of correspondence ?
When designing early Internet services , the focus was on making communication possible .
Therefore , the basic technical protocols have not been taken care to create a solid foundation for a secure correspondence .
Therefore , a conventional e-mail is more like an open postcard than a sealed letter .
If " Anna " user sends a mail to " Benni " , are the computers of the two connected ?
Anna 's email program or browser sends the mail to her service provider 's mail server in the first step .
For example , if it has a GMail account , it would be Google .
This mail server sends the content to the provider Benni uses .
On the route the mail can run over several other servers on the Internet .
Bennie can then call the content from his provider .
Are traditional e-mails being read along their way through the net ?
Most mails are read by software robots on the way .
The sender 's provider usually checks whether the mail contains a malicious program as an attachment .
A virus check is also carried out on the receiver systems .
In addition , providers check whether this is an annoying and unwanted spam mail that is deleted or at least sorted out into a spam folder .
Do the robots have another task ?
For systems like GMail , the robot also determines the information Google needs to place context advertising .
When Anna and Benni communicate via GMail about their upcoming holidays , Google can link to holiday offers .
Do unknown people also read the emails ?
The probability of unauthorized persons reading a message is very low .
In theory , however , this is possible .
In companies , administrators often have the ability to read electronic mail .
The law enforcement agencies and secret services also have legal means of intercepting or taking note of e-mails .
This includes possible illegal spying actions .
Is it possible to protect e-mail from being read ?
With encryption according to the OpenPGP standard , an email can be effectively encrypted against co-reading .
It is also possible , with great technical effort , to conceal the metadata of an email communication , so that it is not even easy to identify who has communicated with whom .

A new day , a new story of terror about independence .

An interesting point is lost in the constant repetition of this ancient history .
Why expect an independent Scotland to dance to the European tune ?
Why replace the London yoke with that of Brussels , especially now ?
These are the real European news : the great postwar plan for European unification has stalled .
With the euro crisis , the European project has officially died .
Across the EU , parties that are hostile to the EU or want to throw the euro out as a single currency are gaining ground .

Even in Germany , the Euroskeptic Alternative für Deutschland party – founded just this year – was able to win nearly five million votes in the September federal election , effectively driving Free Democrats ( the equivalent of the British Liberal Democrats ) out of the Bundestag .
There has always been domestic opposition to the plan to create a federal Europe .
The current economic crisis , however , turns out to be a turning point .

Because of the strict austerity policies imposed by Berlin and the European Central Bank , in conjunction with the straitjacket to which the national economy is being coerced by maintaining the single currency , many people believe that the European project has gone too far .
The euro crisis has little to do with national governments ’ excessive budget deficits – only in Greece .
Instead , the Eurosystem has stuck its members to exchange rates that are beneficial to German exporters – and German politicians would like to leave it that way .
Without the possibility of devaluation of the local currency , southern Europe will find itself with a built-in productivity decline over Germany .
The only way is to cut wages and public spending , spurred by Berlin .
Behind the current budget and currency problems lies a deeper European productivity problem .

As a result of the “ green ” energy directives imposed by Brussels – a code to subsidise French and German energy companies at the expense of consumers – European industry pays twice for electricity and four times for gas compared to the United States .
This is a crippling cost side , as we have already seen in Grangemouth .

As a result , a revolt is looming , especially in France , the EU ’ s former cheerleader .
After the war , France ’ s political elite saw the EU as a vehicle for keeping Germany in check and raising Paris on an equal footing with Washington .

The EU will not disappear , but it will become something more like the “ Europe of ( sovereign ) nations ” favored by General de Gaulle .
Germany and some of its satellite economies may stick to the euro , but France and southern Europe will return to their own currencies .

Indeed , demand in parts of Southeast Asia – where household debt is increasing – is so great that , this week , ValueMax , where it has bartered , became the third pawn listed on the Singaporean stock exchange .
Obtaining jewelry is not only a quick way to get money – 1,300 Singapore dollars in the case of Janani Amirthalinga – but also almost as cheap as an unsecured bank loan .
Typically , pawns in Singapore demand an effective annual rate of 17 % , just above the 15.4 % required by the United Overseas Bank , a local lender with a branch in the same shopping center .
However , deposit houses offer the advantage that there is no need to verify creditworthiness or proof of income , which is why loans are possible faster than banks .
For this reason , millions of people in the region turn to security houses , as families feel the pressure from rising living costs and increasing household and consumer debt .

After five years of robust growth since the global financial crisis and cheap credit due to loose fiscal policies in the developed economies , low-income and middle-income families are looking for security houses to compensate for the difference in struggling economies .
This week , the rating agency Standard & Poor 's growing household debt , mainly due to rising mortgages , described it as a risk factor for the creditworthiness of Asian banks .
According to the agency , Malaysia , Thailand and Singapore have the highest household debt in Asia relative to gross domestic product .
Malaysia is at the top of the list at 80 % of GDP , a 60 % increase in 2008 .
Economic economists are also worried about the high level of consumer debt in Thailand , which has just emerged from a technical recession this week .
On Thursday , the data showed a continuing weakness in exports and a drop in consumer demand .

“ In the end , this means that , with rising costs , people in the middle to lower segments ( the income scale ) will try to supplement their income wherever possible , ” says Song Seng Wun , an economist at CIMB , a Malaysian bank .
Historical highs at gold prices over the past two years have intensified the trend toward pledging personal items , as people take the opportunity to turn the family ’ s jewelry into cash .
In Singapore , about 70 percent of the pledged objects are gold in the city state 's 200 security houses .
People say , “ The gold price looks good , let grandmothers pledge gold chains and get back next month . ”
The largest Thai security house operator , EasyMoney , has experienced a 20 % customer increase in its stores in recent months .

The deposit business growth is so strong that ValueMax , operator of the branch in Bendemeer and 15 others in Singapore , wants to expand not only to neighboring Malaysia – where the company operates four houses – but also outside Asia , according to Yeah Lee Ching , Managing Director of ValueMax .
The company is financing this with 60 % of the 66 million Singapore dollars it received this week in Singapore .

While some lenders have been caught in the crossfire because of high interest rates , Yeah explains that deposit houses not only offer more favorable interest rates than other lenders , but also do not directly raise the debt .

You may not restart them until the aircraft reaches a height of three kilometres and the captain gives the green light .
When boarding , passengers must turn them off and must not start again before the aircraft has landed .

Under the new guidelines , airlines whose aircraft are secured against electronic interference could allow their passengers to use the equipment even at take-off , landing and on the rolling field , the FAA declared .
Most new aircraft and other aircraft that have been converted to higher levels for the use of Wi-Fi should meet the criteria .
Laura Glading , president of the Professional Flight Attendants Association , welcomed the changes .
“ If the new regulation is implemented safely – and we work closely with the airline in this regard – both sides will benefit from it , ” said Glading .

So still not “ Words With Friends ” , the Scrabble like online game that actor Alec Baldwin played on his smartphone in 2011 when he had to leave a jet of American Airlines publicly because he refused to turn off the device while the plane was parked at the boarding gate .
And heavier devices such as laptops must continue to be stowed , as there is a risk of injury if they fly through the cabin .
Mobile phone calls during the flight will also remain prohibited .
The regulatory authority for telephone conversations lies with the Federal Communications Commission ( FCC ) , not the FAA .
FAA may lift a ban on certain electronic devices at launch and landing .
Last month , Mark Rosenker of the National Transportation Safety Board , a national traffic safety expert on CBS News , said that mobile phones are still considered a risk .

“ Mobile phones are really a problem , not only because they could potentially cause disruption to navigation devices , but because we know from the FCC that air transmission can also disrupt transmitter masts , ” says Rosenker .
A consulting committee of the industry , created by the FAA to investigate this issue , recommended last month that the government allow a broader use of personal electronic devices .
In recent years , pressure on FAA has increased to ease restrictions on use .
